items.description: Upper Bristol Avon area
The Rivers Deben and Lark
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low-lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely tomorrow, 21st December 2023. River levels are beginning to drop, but will remain responsive to further rainfall. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for continued unsettled weather over the next couple of days but no significant rainfall is expected. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Thursday 21st December, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn in Gloucestershire
items.message:
River levels are rising at the Mythe Bridge river gauge as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. 
Predicted peaks:- Mythe 2.8m to 3.2m overnight tonight 20/12/23, Haw Bridge 3.85m to 4.2m overnight tonight 20/12/23. No other gauges are impacted.  

We expect river levels to rise during today and remain high for the next few days. Showers are expected over the next 48 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with Local Authorities.  
This message will be updated by 6pm on Wednesday, 20/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Soar in Leicestershire
items.message:
River levels are rising but steady at the Pillings Lock and Kegworth river gauges as a result of persistent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today 20/12/2023. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road and low-lying agricultural land and roads around Cotes, Loughborough, Zouch, Kegworth, Ratcliffe on Soar, Meadow Lane at Loughborough and the access road from Ratcliffe on Soar to Redhill Marina.

No further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

This message will be updated this evening, 20/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
River levels are slowly falling on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water. The lake levels are predicted to keep falling for the next couple of days before more rain on the 23rd and 24th of December. 
Flooding is affecting locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 21/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Churn and its tributaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Churn, Hilcot Brook, Daglingworth Stream, Gumstool Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are falling on the River Churn following recent rainfall. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Cerney Wick area. Today is forecast to be mainly dry. Further light rainfall is expected overnight followed by blustery showers tomorrow. Levels are expected to continue gradually falling over the next few days, but levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 21/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are forecast to rise on the River Cherwell in response to recent rainfall. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Thrupp area. Today is forecast to be mainly dry. Further light rainfall is expected overnight followed by blustery showers tomorrow. Levels are currently falling, but are expected to rise over the next couple of days in response to recent rainfall, especially in the Thrupp area.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 21/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn Vyrnwy confluence
items.message:
River levels have risen at the Llanymynech and Cae Howel river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech.
Peaks :- Llanymynech peaked at 3.38m on Tuesday, 19/12/23; Cae Howel is predicted to peak between 3.8m and 3.9m this morning Wednesday 20/12/2023.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 18:00, 20/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message: River levels remain high around Malton and Low Marishes due to recent persistent rainfall, but continue to fall slowly. Areas most at risk include low lying land around Low Marishes and Yedingham. River levels in Malton are continuing to fall below levels of concern. We continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8:00pm on Wednesday 20/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are slowly rising on the River Glyme in response to recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, especially in the Woodstock area. Today is forecast to be mainly dry. Further light rainfall is expected overnight followed by blustery showers tomorrow. River levels have fallen following previous rain on the River Evenlode, but levels remain high on the River Glyme near Woodstock. We expect levels to continue slowly rising on the River Glyme today.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 21/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are slowly rising on the River Thames. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Abingdon area. Today and overnight is forecast to be mainly dry. Today is forecast to be mainly dry. Further light rainfall is expected overnight followed by blustery showers tomorrow. We expect river levels to continue gradually rising over the next couple days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 21/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and tributaries in the Oxford area
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are currently rising on the River Thames, Seacourt Stream and Bulstake Stream. The risk of flooding of low lying land and roads remains, especially in the Wolvercote and New Botley areas. Today is forecast to be mainly dry. Further light rainfall is expected overnight followed by blustery showers tomorrow. We expect river levels to continue slowly rising over the next couple of days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 21/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Frome and tributaries
items.message:
River levels are remaining high on the Lower Dorset Frome but we have started to see levels falling in the last 48 hours. Levels at our Stinsford and East Stoke Gauges are falling slowly but this alert is likely to remain in force for at least the next 2 days.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Frome, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Dorchester and Wareham.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. The forecast is for rain this evening and during Tuesday before turning more settled on Wednesday. Rivers are likely to respond rapidly to any rainfall.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk, cycle or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 20/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message:
The groundwater level at most of the monitoring boreholes across the Chase remains high, although several have fallen back very slightly over the weekend. A frontal system will pass over the area during Tuesday morning, bringing up to 15mm of rain on higher ground, and due to the saturated nature of the catchment, expect groundwater levels to respond quite quickly. Following a brief dry period through the middle of the week, a return to more unsettled weather will return from Saturday. Homeowners are advised to check any property level resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers. 
Avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave can damage adjacent properties.
This message will be updated on Wednesday the 20th December or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lugg south of Leominster
items.message:
River levels remain high and steady at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.
We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00, 21/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Rivers Blyth and Walpole and Chediston, Bramfield and Wrentham watercourses
items.message: River levels are now steadily falling, but still remain quite high in some locations, particularly around Halesworth. The forecast is for no significant rainfall over the next few days. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Middle Avon and tributaries
items.message:
River levels are falling slowly but remain high in the Middle Hampshire Avon and its Tributaries due to rainfall in the last 24 hours and additional significant contributions to river flow from rising groundwater levels.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Salisbury and Ringwood.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 21/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are currently rising on the River Thames. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected this morning, especially in the Rushey and Eynsham areas. Today is forecast to be mainly dry. Further light rainfall is expected overnight followed by blustery showers tomorrow. River levels are forecast to continue slowly rising over the next couple of days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 21/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message:

Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, particularly in the Arncott and Islip areas. Today is forecast to be mainly dry. Further light rainfall is expected overnight followed by blustery showers tomorrow. River levels are forecast to continue rising over the next couple of days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. items.description: Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes
items.message: The Aldingbourne Rife remains high, but is now slowly falling. Minor flooding is still thought to be affecting fields, land and caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and parts of the Tesco car park on Shripney Road. The Barnham Rife has already fallen nearer to normal levels. Very little rain is forecast for the next five days, and so the Aldingbourne Rife should continue to fall and flood impacts ease. However, the Aldingbourne Rife might not return to normal levels until the new year. Water levels will remain sensitive to any additional rainfall over the rest of winter. Some roads could be affected by flood water. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Shripney Lane. We are clearing grilles through Barnham, and our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. We will re-issue this Flood Alert if the risk of flooding increases.

items.description: River Thames and its small tributaries from Calcutt to Lechlade

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thames, Blunsdon Brook, Water Eaton Brook, Marston Meysey Brook, Share Ditch, Bydemill Brook, Westrop Brook, Downington Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are currently rising on the River Thames and small tributaries. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected this morning, especially in the Hannington area. Today is forecast to be mainly dry. Further light rainfall is expected overnight followed by blustery showers tomorrow. We expect river levels to continue rising today, but will then gradually fall over the next few days. Levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 21/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Wednesday 20th December and into the weekend. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to the natural tide locking effect. Tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, restricts the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. Water levels also remain high around Wayford Bridge and Hoveton Broad. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Thursday 21st December, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Hull catchment

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Hull, Holderness Drain, Barmston Drain

items.message:
"River levels remain high on Beverley and Barmston Drain, Frodingham Beck, the River Hull and Roam Drain due to recent prolonged rainfall and elevated groundwater levels. Areas most at risk are around the rivers and drains between Frodingham Bridge and the Wilfholme area.

Levels are expected to stay high for several days but are expected to fall slowly. On Roam Drain, levels are still rising slowly with the areas most at risk including low lying land around Hempholme. We are operating pumps in the area. We continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 08:00pm on Wednesday 20/12/2023, or as the situation changes."

items.description: Lower River Derwent

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire, York

items.message: River levels remain high on the Lower River Derwent at Thornton Lock and Elvington due to recent persistent rainfall. We expect levels to remain high for the next few days but to continue falling slowly. Levels at Buttercrambe and Stamford Bridge have continued to fall and are below levels of concern, but floodwater is likely to remain on low lying land for a number of days. We are monitoring levels closely and have staff checking flood defences in the area. Continue acting on your flood plan. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8:00pm on Wednesday 20/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Avon and tributaries

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
River levels are remaining high in the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon and tributaries and are rising in response to the rainfall in the last 24 hours and additional significant contributions to river flow from rising groundwater levels.

Levels are forecast to remain above the Flood Alert level for at least the next 3 days. 

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 21/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message:
The groundwater level at most of the monitoring boreholes in the West of Dorset remains high, although most have fallen back very slightly over the weekend. A frontal system will pass over the area during Tuesday morning, bringing up to 15mm of rain on higher ground, and due to the saturated nature of the catchment, expect groundwater levels to respond quite quickly. Following a brief dry period through the middle of the week, a return to more unsettled weather will return from Saturday. Homeowners are advised to check any property level resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers. 
Avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave can damage adjacent properties.
This message will be updated on Wednesday the 20th December or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Piddle and tributaries
items.message:
River levels are remaining high but starting to recede on the River Piddle following the recent rainfall and additional contributions to river flow from rising groundwater levels.

Flooding is possible at tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. The forecast is for rain this evening and during Tuesday before turning more settled on Wednesday. Rivers are likely to respond rapidly to any rainfall.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 04:00 PM on 20/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are continuing to rise. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for continued unsettled weather over the next couple of days but no significant rainfall is expected. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Thursday 21st December, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Rodington and Walcot river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.
We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.  We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 18:00, 20/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are falling on the River Leach following recent rainfall. The risk of flooding of low lying land and roads remains, especially in the Lechlade area. Today is forecast to be mainly dry. Further light rainfall is expected overnight followed by blustery showers tomorrow. We expect river levels will gradually fall over the next few days, but levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 21/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The River Waveney from Diss and the River Dove to Ellingham, including Bungay
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low-lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely tomorrow, Thursday 21st December, 2023. The River Waveney is rising steadily in response to the rainfall. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for continued unsettled weather over the next couple of days but no significant rainfall is expected. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation.  We will update this message on Thursday, 21st December, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to rainfall over the past few weeks and remain high at our observation borehole in Draycot Foliat in the Og Valley area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and remain at a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater over the coming weeks.
The groundwater level at Draycot Foliat is higher than normal for this time of year but groundwater levels are currently declining. The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and groundwater levels and may start to rise again if there is further rainfall. Low-lying land, gardens, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.
We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 23/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Chertsey Bourne

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are high on the Chertsey Bourne following yesterday's rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low-lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Chertsey area. It is forecast to be mainly dry today, 20/12/2023. We expect river levels to remain high throughout the day.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

This message will be updated this evening, 20/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mid Bristol Avon area

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels are falling on the Bristol Avon and Semington Brook.  Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.  Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
Small amounts of rain are forecast over the next few days and river levels are expected to keep falling.
We will continue to monitor the weather forecast and river levels closely.
This message will be updated by the evening of Wednesday 20th December, or sooner if the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8,09m and stable. This level is being maintained by water being pumped off the moor.
The pumping station drain level is 8.09m and falling slowly in response to pumping activities. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.30m, from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86m, and from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93m. Property flooding is expected when this level exceeds 8.35m. 
The forecast for the remainder of the week is favourable with blustery conditions and occasional showers likely.
We are currently pumping at Westover and Huish Episcopi pumping stations and will continue to clear as much water from the moors as river levels allow. Please remain mindful of local water levels and do not attempt to drive, cycle or walk through flood water.
Please refer to @TravelSomerset for information on closed roads.
This message will be updated by 10am on Thursday 21/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hambledon
items.message: In Hambledon, groundwater levels are high and continue to rise. Since Tuesday 12/12/2023, just 12mm of rain has been recorded at Worlds End. The groundwater level at Whitedale Farm has risen by 3.11m during that time. Ongoing cellar flooding will be affecting a significant number of properties on West Street and East Street. Groundwater will be affecting the sewerage system, and Fareham Road is currently flooded. Today (Tuesday 19/12/2023), up to 13mm of rain is forecast in Hampshire. Dry weather is expected from Wednesday (20/12/2023) to Saturday (23/12/2023). Groundwater is expected to peak by the end of the week. More properties are expected to be impacted by cellar flooding in this time. We are liaising with Hambledon Flood Action Group and continue to monitor the situation. If you use pumps to reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Friday 22/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle
items.message: In Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle, groundwater levels are high and continue to rise slowly. In the last week, just 13mm of rain has been recorded at Walderton, and the groundwater level at Finchdean has risen by 18cm. The Idsworth and Chalton Lavants are flowing. Pumps which prevent water from entering property may be required for properties in all villages. It is possible that road flooding will be ongoing throughout the area. Surface water flooding may occur during heavier rain events. Today (Tuesday 19/12/2023), up to 13mm of rain is forecast in Hampshire. Dry weather is expected from Wednesday (20/12/2023) to Saturday (23/12/2023). The groundwater level is expected to peak early next week. We are liaising with the Flood Action Group. Please remove valuables from cellars, and ensure pumps used to reduce water levels can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Friday 22/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to the recent rainfall across the area and have risen at our observation borehole in Longacre in the Lambourn Valley. Groundwater levels are higher than normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected within the next few days by flooding from groundwater.
The groundwater level at Longacre is higher than normal for this time of year but is currently very slowly declining. The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and groundwater levels and may start to rise again if there is further rainfall. Low-lying land, gardens, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.
We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 22/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tributaries of the lower River Witham from Blankney to Sleaford

floodArea.riverOrSea: Kyme Eau, River Slea, Billinghay Skirth, Ruskington Beck, Old River Slea and Leasingham Beck

items.message: River levels are gradually falling, they do however remain high in the Blankney to Sleaford area. Further rainfall last night will keep river levels high for the next few days. Flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to rivers. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on Floodline by 13:00 on 21st December 2023, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: River Hull Central catchment

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, Kingston upon Hull
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Hull, Beverley and Barmston Drain

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Hull due to recent rainfall, high groundwater levels and the effect of the tides. Flooding may affect locations near the Beverley and Barmston Drain and River Hull, with low lying land expected to be most affected, including the central River Hull area around Arram, Tickton, Beverley, and Dunswell. River levels are expected to remain high for a number of days. We are in the area operating pumping stations and checking defences, as well as operating flood defences across the wider catchment area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8:00pm on Wednesday 20/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
River levels are falling but remain high at the Torksey river gauge as a result of high tides coinciding with high river levels. Consequently the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road, Lea Marsh, Gainsborough, Morton, East and West Stockwith, Trent Wharfage and Gainsborough Railway Bridge.
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Showery rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. 
This message will be updated by 18:00 this evening, 20/12/23 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Tamar
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Tamar, River Strat, River Neet, River Ottery, River Kensey

items.message: The risk of flooding from the river has now reduced, and river levels are falling below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

items.description: River Sow and River Penk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.description: River Stour and Smestow Brook in the Black Country and South Staffordshire
Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message:
River levels have fallen at the Clay Coton gauge but remain high at the Lilbourne gauge as a result of rainfall yesterday.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is continues into today, 20/12/23.  Flooding is likely to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne.   
We expect river levels to continue to fall until later this afternoon.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 18:00 on 20/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Avon in Worcestershire
Bow and Piddle Brook
items.message:
River levels are rising at the Besford Bridge river gauge as a result of recent rainfall. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the Brooks from Webheath to Defford. Other locations that may be affected include Crowle, Wickenham, Peopleton, Pinvin and Pershore. Local fords may also be flooded. 
Showers are expected over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to remain high in the coming days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with Local Authorities. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 6pm on Wednesday 20/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Leam and River Itchen
items.message:
River levels have risen at the Eathorpe gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible between 08:00 and 22:00 today, 20/12/23.  We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leam between Grandborough and Leamington including Kites Hardwick, Birdingbury, Marton, Eathorpe, Hunningham and Offchurch and the River Itchen between Southam and Marton including Long Itchington    
 We expect river levels to rise until later this evening.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 18:00 on 20/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Salwarpe
River Leadon catchment
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Showers are expected over the next 48 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: River Frome in Herefordshire
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels are rising at the Bromyard, Bishops Frome and Yarkhill river gauges, however they are below and no longer forecast to reach the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

items.description: Upper Teme

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Teme, River Onny, River Corve

items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and will re-issue this alert if necessary. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

items.description: Ledwyche Brook and River Rea
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and will re-issue this alert if necessary. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

items.description: River Cole, Dorcan Brook and South Marston Brook
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  
Today is forecast to be mainly dry. Further light rainfall is expected overnight followed by blustery showers tomorrow. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: Upper River Stour
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.riverOrSea: Great Stour, East Stour, Aylesford Stream, Ruckinge Dyke, Whitewater Dyke, Stour

items.message:
River levels are rising on the Upper Stour due to yesterday’s rainfall.
 
Flooding is forecast to affect low lying land and roads along the Upper Stour, particularly in and around Chart Leacon and Victoria Park from this morning.
 
No property flooding is expected. Drier conditions over the next couple of days.
 
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
 
This message will be updated by 08:00 PM on 20/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Riseley Brook in Bedford Borough
items.message: River levels are now falling after yesterday’s rainfall. Areas most at risk are around the Riseley Brook from Riseley to Pertenhall. The weather forecast is unsettled but largely dry for several days, which should allow river levels to continue falling. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 6pm today, 20/12/23.

items.description: Rothley Brook and Quorn Brook in Leicestershire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.   No further rainfall is forecast. 
We continue to monitor the situation. 
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.description: River Sence in Leicestershire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has now been removed.
River levels at the South Wigston river gauge are rising but steady and below the flood risk threshold.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. No further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.description: Upper River Great Ouse in Northamptonshire, Oxfordshire and Buckinghamshire

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Milton Keynes, Oxfordshire, West Northamptonshire

items.message: River levels are steadily falling. The weather forecast is unsettled but mostly dry for several days, which should allow river levels to continue falling.

items.description: River Tove in Northamptonshire
items.message: River levels are steadily falling. The weather forecast is unsettled but mostly dry for several days, which should allow river levels to continue falling.

items.description: River Wreake in Leicestershire
items.message:
River levels have risen but are steady at the Frisby river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today 20/12/2023. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Mill Lane and Water Lane at Frisby on the Wreake, Station Road at Thrussington, Broome Lane at Ratcliffe on the Wreake, Frisby, farmlands at Hoby, Brooksby, Thrussington, Ratcliffe and Syston. Flooding of farm land and low lying roads in the Melton and Asfordby areas, including Station Lane Asfordby.

No further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

This message will be updated this evening, 20/12/2023 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Great Ouse in Cambridgeshire from Brampton to Earith
items.message: River levels are rising steadily in response to yesterday's rainfall. Flooding of low-lying land is possible during the next few days. Areas most at risk are around the River Great Ouse from Brampton to Earith, including Back Brook, Hall Green Brook, Parsons Drove Drain, Swavesey Drain and Wadsbys Folly. Access to properties in Berry Lane, Godmanchester, may also be affected. The weather forecast is unsettled but mostly dry for several days, which should allow river levels to start falling soon. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 6pm today, 20/12/23.

items.description: Weymouth Rivers and Streams
items.message:
River levels are remaining high on the River Wey, Preston Brook, River Jordan due to rising groundwater levels.

Levels at our Broadway gauge are starting to slowly fall but are likely to remain above the flood alert level for at least the next 2 days.

The forecast this evening and into Tuesday is for rain to return. River levels are likely to respond rapidly.

Flooding is possible at the River Wey to Radipole Lake, Preston Brook and River Jordan.

We are monitoring river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 16:00 on 20/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Wey
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are high on the Upper River Wey following yesterday's rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low-lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Godalming area. It is forecast to be mainly dry today, 20/12/2023. We expect river levels to gradually fall over the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

This message will be updated this evening, 20/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Cam in Cambridgeshire
items.message: River levels are rising steadily in response to yesterday's rainfall. Flooding of low-lying land is possible during the next few days. Areas most at risk are around the River Cam from Stapleford to Waterbeach. The weather forecast is unsettled but mostly dry for several days, which should allow river levels to start falling soon. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 6pm today, 20/12/23.

items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are slowly rising on the River Windrush in response to recent rainfall. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected today, especially in the Newbridge area. Today is forecast to be mainly dry. Further light rainfall is expected overnight followed by blustery showers tomorrow. We expect levels to continue to rise slowly today.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 21/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Rhee in Central Bedfordshire, Hertfordshire and Cambridgeshire
items.message: River levels are slowly rising in response to yesterday’s rainfall. Flooding of low-lying land is possible during the next few days. Areas most at risk are those around the River Rhee from Guilden Morden to Haslingfield. The weather forecast is unsettled but mostly dry for several days, which should allow river levels to start falling soon. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 6pm today, 20/12/23.

items.description: Kempsey Village
River Severn in Worcestershire
Low lying properties in the Upper Hull catchment
items.message: River levels in the Upper River Hull catchment remain high due to recent rainfall and elevated groundwater levels. Areas most at risk include the River Hull and tributaries at Frodingham, Hempholme, Wilfholme and Burshill. River levels are expected to remain high for several days and we are operating pumps in the area. We continue to monitor the situation. Put your flood plan into action, avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8:00pm on Wednesday 20/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message: River levels remain high in response to recent rainfall. Flooding is expected on the Hundred Foot (Ouse) Washes for several days. This information is correct as of 7:30am on 20/12/23. The causeway at Earith may have some standing water on the road. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 25cm of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has approximately 37cm of water on the road. Norfolk County Council have closed Welney causeway. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. Floodwater is travelling down the River Great Ouse towards the Ouse Washes which will keep levels high for several days. Avoid driving through floodwater. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 4pm today, 20/12/23.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Dean, Singleton, Charlton, East Dean and Chilgrove
items.message: Above average rainfall has been measured between October and December 2023. Groundwater is high, and close to the surface. Minor groundwater flood impacts are expected to continue, with water flowing on roads, in basements or under floorboards, and affecting the ability of the sewage network to operate in East Dean, Charlton, Singleton and West Dean. Water could also affect the B2141 at Chilgrove. 15mm of rain is forecast Tuesday 19/12/2023, but then no rain to Sunday 24/12/2023. Groundwater at Chilgrove's borehole, is expected to continue falling, but with a temporary slowing Thursday and Friday. At the East Dean borehole, groundwater will stay at the surface. Flood impacts are expected to remain until the middle of January, and potentially longer or affecting more people if wet weather returns. Groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any additional rainfall over winter. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 21/12/2023

items.description: Minor Watercourses from Heighington to Dunston
items.message: River levels are gradually falling, they do however remain high in the Heighington to Dunston area. Further rainfall last night will keep river levels high for the next few days. Flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to rivers. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on Floodline by 13:00 on 21st December 2023, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the South Winterbourne Valley
items.message:
The level at Kingston Russell borehole has fallen back very slightly over the weekend, however with up to 15mm of rainfall forecast over the next 24 hours a further, small upward rise is possible before things settle back down towards the latter part of the week. This may see a re-appearance of flood water on roads in Martinstown and the Winterbourne villages and possibly on the A354 west of Winterbourne Abbas, although the impact will be rather less than was experienced over the last two weeks.
Householders are advised to check property level resilience measures including, pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers. Do not drive through flood water unless absolutely necessary as the bow wave can cause damage to nearby properties.
this message will be updated on Wednesday the 20th December or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Colne and Radlett Brook
items.message:
River levels have now fallen following heavy rainfall on Tuesday 19th December. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. 
There is no more heavy rainfall forecast over the next 3 days and we do not expect river levels to rise again. We recommend that you avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses as there may still be standing water in some locations. 
Our incident response staff are constantly monitoring the situation and are ready to respond if required. We recommend that you remain aware of the forecast for the next 5 days.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Piddle Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels at the Doles Ash borehole have settled back a little over the weekend, but remain very high for the time of year. Up to 15mm of rainfall is expected over the next 24 hours and this may well trigger a small increase in level. This may lead to flooding of roads and cellars. After a brief drier spell a return to more unsettled weather is forecast for the remainder of the month.
Householders should check that any property level resilience measures they have in place such as pumps, flood barriers or air brick covers are still working effectively. Motorists are advised to avoid driving through flood water wherever possible as the bow wave from vehicles can cause damage to nearby properties. 
This message will be updated on Wednesday 20th December or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Rattlesden River and River Gipping, through and including Stowmarket and Needham Market
items.message: River levels are now steadily falling, but may still remain high in some locations. The forecast is for continued unsettled weather over the next couple of days but no significant rainfall is expected. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: River Dikler from Condicote to Little Rissington
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are falling on the River Dikler following recent rainfall. The risk of flooding of low lying land and roads remains, especially in the Bourton On The Water area. Today is forecast to be mainly dry. Further light rainfall is expected overnight followed by blustery showers tomorrow. River levels are expected to gradually fall over the next few days, but levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 21/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Ginge Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are falling on the Ginge Brook following recent rainfall. The risk of flooding of low lying land and roads remains, especially in the Steventon area. Today is forecast to be mainly dry. Further light rainfall is expected overnight followed by blustery showers tomorrow. River levels are expected to continue slowly falling today, but levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 21/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to strong winds coinciding with today’s high tide. Weather conditions may produce large waves and spray overtopping of defences.

Areas most at risk include the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir.

No property flooding is expected.

The peak tide level is expected at 12:30 PM on Wednesday 20/12/2023. Flooding is possible for an hour either side of this time. The tide height is 4.21 m AOD with a Force 7 westerly wind. 

Strong winds are also forecast for Thursday. This may mean similar impacts for tomorrow’s high tides. We will continue to monitor the forecast and will re-issue this alert if necessary.

Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 21/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in upper River Ems Valley
items.message: Above average rainfall has been measured between October and December 2023. Groundwater is high, and close to the surface, but currently slowly falling at the Compton borehole. Minor groundwater flood impacts will continue, with springs affecting fields, the village green Stoughton, and rural roads including Stoughton main road, the road from East Marden and also between Cooks Lane and The Barley Mow, and the B2146 near Woodlands Lane, in Walderton. 15mm of rain is forecast Tuesday 19/12/2023, but with no rain Wednesday to Sunday 24/12/2023. Despite Tuesday's rain, groundwater is expected to continue to slowly fall through to next week. If  groundwater rises following Tuesday's rain, it should peak by Sunday 24/12/2023, not significantly higher than recent heights. Groundwater will remain higher than normal, sensitive to any additional rainfall, with risk of flood over the winter. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 21/12/2023

items.description: River Kennet from Thatcham down to Reading
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are rising on the lower River Kennet in response to recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible today, especially in the Theale area. Today is forecast to be mainly dry. Further light rainfall is expected overnight followed by blustery showers tomorrow. We expect river levels to continue rising today in response to recent rainfall. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 21/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Mardyke to the River Thames at Purfleet
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Wednesday 20th December 2023. River levels are currently high, but are expected to start to drop back down to more normal levels later today, following Tuesday's rain. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for continued unsettled weather over the next couple of days but no significant rainfall. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Thursday 21st December, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Patcham
items.message: Above average rainfall has been measured between October and December 2023. Groundwater is high and close to the surface, but slowly falling at the Ladies Mile borehole. 15mm of rain is forecast Tuesday 19/12/2023, but with no rain Wednesday to Sunday 24/12/2023. Despite the rain Tuesday, groundwater at Ladies Mile borehole is likely to continue falling through to the weekend. However, the rate of fall could slow. If the maximum predicted rainfall, or more, occurs, groundwater could possibly rise again, however groundwater flood impacts are not currently thought likely this week. Previous events suggest impacts may initially affect Old London Road, Patcham and Peacock Lane, Withdean. Groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any additional rainfall over winter. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We will continue to monitor levels and forecasts and liaise with Brighton and Hove City Council. We will update this message by 18:00 21/12/2023

items.description: River Bourne and tributaries
items.message:
River levels are remaining high but starting to recede at the Salisbury Bourne river gauge on the River Bourne due to the recent rainfall and additional contributions to river flow from rising groundwater levels. Levels at our Ebbesbourne Wake and Salisbury gauges are receding but remain high.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Bourne, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Aughton and Laverstock.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. The forecast is for rain this evening and during Tuesday before turning more settled on Wednesday.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 20/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: Groundwater levels in villages surrounding Andover are high, and continuing to rise in response to the rainfall received over the last month. We expect groundwater to be affecting cellars in Appleshaw, the sewer network in Penton Mewsey, and the main road at Penton Grafton. In the next 3 days, cellar flooding is also expected in Hatherden. Tomorrow (Tuesday 19/12/2023), up to 20mm of rain is forecast in Hampshire. Dry weather is expected from Wednesday (20/12/2023) to Friday (22/12/2023). Groundwater is expected to continue rising. We expect the spring at Biddesden to flow from Friday (22/12/2023). Cellar flooding in Penton Grafton and groundwater emergence into Deacon and Down Road, Kimpton is possible by the end of the week. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please remove valuables from cellars and if you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Friday 22/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hursley
items.message: In Hursley, groundwater levels are high and have risen 92cm in the last week. We expect cellar flooding in the south end of the village to be occurring imminently. From Wednesday 20/12/2023, cellar flooding could occur at the Dolphin Inn pub, and impacts to the sewerage network could be experienced. Today (Tuesday 19/12/2023), up to 13mm of rain is forecast in Hampshire. Dry weather is expected from Wednesday (20/12/2023) to Saturday (23/12/2023). Groundwater is expected to continue rising. We expect that more cellars in Hursley will begin to experience flooding impacts during that time. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This message will be updated by 17:00 on Friday 22/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the North Winterborne, north of the A354
items.message:
Groundwater levels at the Delcombe Wood borehole have settled back a little over the weekend, but remain very high for the time of year. Up to 15mm of rainfall is expected over the next 24 hours and this may well trigger a small increase in level. This may lead to flooding of roads and cellars. After a brief drier spell a return to more unsettled weather is forecast for the remainder of the month.
Householders should check that any property level resilience measures they have in place such as pumps, flood barriers or air brick covers are still working effectively. Motorists are advised to avoid driving through flood water wherever possible as the bow wave from vehicles can cause damage to nearby properties. 
This message will be updated on Wednesday 20th December or as the situation change

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Bere Stream
items.message:
Groundwater levels at the Delcombe Wood borehole have settled back a little over the weekend, but remain very high for the time of year. Up to 15mm of rainfall is expected over the next 24 hours and this may well trigger a small increase in level. This may lead to flooding of roads and cellars. After a brief drier spell a return to more unsettled weather is forecast for the remainder of the month.
Householders should check that any property level resilience measures they have in place such as pumps, flood barriers or air brick covers are still working effectively. items.description: Groundwater flooding for the North Winterborne, south of the A354
items.message:
Groundwater levels at the Delcombe Wood borehole have settled back a little over the weekend, but remain very high for the time of year. Up to 15mm of rainfall is expected over the next 24 hours and this may well trigger a small increase in level. This may lead to flooding of roads and cellars. After a brief drier spell a return to more unsettled weather is forecast for the remainder of the month.
Householders should check that any property level resilience measures they have in place such as pumps, flood barriers or air brick covers are still working effectively. Motorists are advised to avoid driving through flood water wherever possible as the bow wave from vehicles can cause damage to nearby properties. 
This message will be updated on Wednesday 20th December or as the situation change

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Meon Valley from East Meon to Soberton
items.message: In the Meon Valley, groundwater levels are high but slowly falling following a week of mostly dry weather. The winterbourne has been flowing in Meonstoke for several weeks and there is a small amount of water ponded around the electricity sub-station in Rectory Lane. Today (Tuesday 19/12/2023), up to 13mm of rain is forecast in Hampshire. Dry weather is expected from Wednesday (20/12/2023) to Saturday (23/12/2023). Groundwater levels are expected to continue falling during that time. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Cellar flooding caused by groundwater remains a possibility this winter. Please remain prepared. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please check that they can operate effectively. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Friday 22/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Salisbury Plain area
items.message:
The groundwater level at most of the monitoring boreholes across Salisbury Plain continue to rise quite slowly. On the West Wiltshire downs including the Wylye Valley and the Vale of Wardour, levels have settled back a bit over the weekend. 
 A frontal system will pass over the area during Tuesday morning, bringing up to 10mm of rain on higher ground, and due to the saturated nature of the catchment, expect groundwater levels to respond quite quickly. Following a brief dry period through the middle of the week, a return to more unsettled weather will return from Saturday. Homeowners are advised to check any property level resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers. 
Avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave can damage adjacent properties.
This message will be updated on Wednesday the 20th December or as the situation changes.

items.description: North West Norfolk Rivers
items.message: River levels are now falling after yesterday’s rainfall. Flooding of low-lying land is possible and there may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Areas most at risk are those around the Heacham River, The Ingol, Babingley River and Gaywood River. The weather forecast is largely dry for several days, which should allow river levels to continue falling. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 6pm today, 20/12/23.

items.description: The upper Stour and surrounding tributaries
items.message: River levels are now returning to normal. The forecast is for no significant rainfall for the next few days. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Twyford and Hensting
items.message: In Twyford and Hensting, groundwater levels are high and rising. In the last 2 months, prolonged, much higher than average rainfall (365mm) was recorded at Otterbourne. In the last 24 hours, the groundwater level at our borehole in West Meon Hut has risen by 17cm. In the next 4 days, cellar flooding will begin to affect a small number of properties in Twyford and Hensting. Today (Tuesday 19/12/2023), up to 13mm of rain is forecast in Hampshire. Dry weather is expected from Wednesday (20/12/2023) to Saturday (23/12/2023). Groundwater is expected to continue rising. Minor impact flooding to Hensting Lane could occur from early next week. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Friday 22/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Vernham Dean, Upton and the Bourne Valley
items.message: In the Bourne Valley, groundwater levels are high and rising. In the last 2 months, prolonged, much higher than average rainfall (298mm) has been recorded in Andover. At Vernham Dean, the current rate of rise is 34cm per day. In the next 5 days, groundwater flooding will affect a small number of cellars in Upton. Septic tanks will also struggle to operate properly. We do not expect significant impacts to property at Vernham Dean, Hurstbourne Tarrant, Stoke or St Marybourne until later this winter. Today (Tuesday 19/12/2023), up to 13mm of rain is forecast in Hampshire. Dry weather is expected from Wednesday (20/12/2023) to Saturday (23/12/2023). Groundwater is expected to continue rising. We will continue to monitor the forecast. In Upton, please remove any valuables from cellars and if you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure they can operate. We advise all residents in the Bourne Valley to remain prepared for potential impacts over the next few weeks. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Friday 22/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Bramdean and Cheriton
items.message: In Bramdean and Cheriton, groundwater levels are high and rising. In the last 2 months, prolonged, much higher than average rainfall (364mm) was recorded at Bishops Sutton. In the last 24 hours, the groundwater level at our borehole in West Meon Hut has increased by 17cm. In the next 4 days, cellar flooding will begin to affect a small number of cellars in Cheriton. It is unlikely that cellar flooding will affect property in Bramdean for another few weeks. Today (Tuesday 19/12/2023), up to 13mm of rain is forecast in Hampshire. Dry weather is expected from Wednesday (20/12/2023) to Saturday (23/12/2023). Groundwater is expected to continue rising. Septic tanks could struggle to operate effectively from early next week. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Friday 22/12/2023.

items.description: Upper River Cam in Essex and Cambridgeshire
items.message: River levels are high in response to yesterday’s rainfall. Flooding of low-lying land is possible during the next few days. Areas most at risk are those around the River Cam from Newport to Whittlesford including the Slades. The weather forecast is unsettled but mostly dry for several days, which should allow river levels to start falling soon. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 6pm today, 20/12/23.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in East Kent
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
Groundwater levels in East Kent have been rising due to the high amount of rainfall we had in October and November. In response to this groundwater level increase, communities in and around the Elham Valley (Nailbourne), Alkham and Petham may experience impacts from high groundwater. Due to the nature of groundwater levels, other communities across East Kent may also experience increased impact from high groundwater. The Environment Agency is continually monitoring the situation and we are co-ordinating efforts with local authorities and community leaders. Our incident response staff are attending weedscreens and culverts regularly to clear them.

We are issuing this message to allow our communities and partners to act as appropriate.
 
This event may continue for the foreseeable future and until the end of the recharge season, typically in Spring 2024. We will update this message as required, or sooner if the situation changes significantly.
 
To find out more information please visit: www.gov.uk/government/publications/kent-groundwater-situation

items.description: River Wissey in Norfolk
items.message: River levels are rising steadily in response to yesterday's rainfall. Flooding of low-lying land is possible during the next few days. Areas most at risk are those around the River Wissey from Bradenham to Denver including Watton Brook. The weather forecast is unsettled but mostly dry for several days, which should allow river levels to start falling soon. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 6pm today, 20/12/23.
